Blurb
Overview
This applied module uses research-connected teaching and field biology to explore contemporary thinking and practice in conservation biology in a practical setting. Students are encouraged to explore patterns of biodiversity and to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or decline of many animal and plant species. This equips students with the knowledge and skills to critically evaluate different approaches to conserving biodiversity at a range of locations including local nature reserves, agri-environment schemes and other non-designated areas.

The module is taught via lectures, tutorials and a series of non-residential field trips, where students will be tutored by, and work with site managers and practitioners to apply their understanding of biodiversity conservation. To support independent learning, students will also be guided to references, primary and secondary sources, listed by staff.

The module is assessed by an Invasive Species Action Plan and a site management plan.
Educational Aims
• develop in students knowledge and understanding about patterns of biodiversity and to enable them to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or decline of some animal and plant species.

• develop in students knowledge and deep understanding in conservation biology, and ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve complex problems in a real world setting.

• develop in students an awareness of the employment opportunities in conservation biology and what it takes to be career ready.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This applied module uses research-connected teaching, Geographical Information System (GIS) workshops, and field biology to explore contemporary thinking and practice in conservation biology in a practical setting. Students are encouraged to explore patterns of biodiversity and to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or decline of many animal and plant species. This equips students with the knowledge and skills to critically evaluate different approaches to conserving biodiversity at a range of local nature reserves and also in a global setting. Throughout the module, emphasis is placed on evidence-based approaches to conservation and how data gained are used to achieve maximally effective conservation and management.

The module is taught via lectures, tutorials and a series of non-residential field trips, where students will be tutored by, and work with site managers and conservation practitioners to apply their understanding of biodiversity conservation.

Students will gain practical experience of working on nature reserves that will prepare them for employment. They will develop their planning, management and leadership skills in conservation as well as an in-depth knowledge of applying QGIS to conservation questions. To support independent learning, students will also be guided to references, primary and secondary sources, listed by staff.

The module is assessed by an Invasive Species Action Plan and a Reserve Management Plan.

The module is aimed at students studying Biological Science, Bioveterinary Science and Zoology. The module will be of interest to students wishing to learn more about conservation biology, including those who wish to pursue a career in conservation or applied ecology.
Outline Syllabus
Theme: The bigger picture in Conservation Biology

This theme focuses on the scale and rate of species loss and fundamental causes of biodiversity erosion. Aspects of conservation biology that will be considered include, overexploitation of wildlife populations, the effects of climate change, and causes of habitat loss and disturbance. This will be taught through lectures and field visits.

Theme: Metapopulations and Conservation Genetics/Genomics

In this theme students will explore the importance of habitat area, fragmentation and connectivity and apply this to their understanding of species viability and to prioritise conservation efforts. They will study conservation genetics and use their understanding of species concepts, hybridization, genetic diversity, demographic history and effective population size to prioritise choices of species and protected areas. This will be taught through lectures and field visits.

Theme: Climate change and conservation

In this theme students will examine how climate change interferes with established conservation practices and necessitates different plans to achieve conservation goals

Theme: Decision making in conservation

In this theme students will explore how conservationists prioritise when making decisions about conservation practice and which areas and species to protect.

Theme: Economics of conservation

In this theme student will consider frameworks such as ‘land sparing-sharing’ which originated for quantifying and understanding the implications for wild species of using land in different ways to produce food. Students will also review ‘Eco-harvesting’. Students will also consider ‘Ecosystem services.’

Theme: Conservation practice

In this theme students will explore UK and Global conservation issues including invasive and alien species and hunting, lessons from past extinctions, captive breeding reintroductions, restoration, and designing nature reserves

Theme: Conservation careers

Students will work alongside conservationists and habitat managers and develop knowledge and skills in practical habitat management and species conservation, multiagency working, UK and global legislation and funding for conservation.
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week will involve watching pre-recorded material introducing the nature reserve, risk assessment etc, a 50 minute face to face lecture introducing key theory and a full day field visit. A tutorial will cover post-fieldwork discussions. There will be a block of workshops dedicated to teaching graphical information systems (GIS).

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled online lectures in which key concepts are explained and active learning tasks are set. There is one introductory lecture to each field trip. Each field trip will be preceded by a synchronous fieldwork preparation e-lecture.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 – Tutorials
Description: This refers to face-to-face tutorials to provide fieldwork follow-up
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 – workshops
Description: This refers to training students how to use QGIS
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 4 - Field trips
Description: This refers to site visits to various nature reserves, agri-schemes or other non-designated areas in the North West where students will be taught by, and work with conservation practitioners
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching method 5 – Self-directed learning
Description: This refers to independent study from online resources and texts, encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of virtual models, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, fieldwork, revision study and work towards assessment.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Due to the novel nature of the assessments students will receive formative feedback.

Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc and many hours of fieldwork. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Because the assessments are novel students are provided with formative feedback. The ISAP and the Reserve Management Plan are highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge and application in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning, using GIS, and real world case-based-learning etc. These foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures and field trips are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Both assessments require students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: Organisms and ecosystems are studied at a local and global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Lecture content, and discussion between students and staff will have a global perspective and give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1. Invasive Species Action Plan (ISAP)
Professional ecologists and conservations are sometimes required to write Invasive Species Action Plans. Students will use GB Non-native Species Secretariat templates in order to complete this work and follow guidance set by the GB Invasive Non-native Species Strategy. As this is a novel assessment students will be provided with published ISAPs. They will also be given prescriptive guidance on how to complete the task which consist of six elements:
• Task 1. Rapid Risk Assessment – used to assess the likelihood and severity of the threat - completed form submitted in appendix with ISAP
• Task 2. Risk Management – used to evaluate management options - completed form submitted in appendix with ISAP
• Task 3. ISAP – produce an ISAP
• Task 4. NNSS ID sheet– produce an ID sheet
• Task 5. NNSS Species Fact Sheet (Alert Species)
• Task 6. Risk Communications Plan – the means by which the results of risk analysis are summarised and accurately communicated. You are not going to generate one of these but you simply need to say how you would communicate your findings

This is worth 40% of the overall module mark. There is a reassessment opportunity in the normal reassessment period capped at 40%

Assessment 2. Site management plan
Nature reserves often require both a short and long term site management plan that is written by the site manager and is a legally binding document. Throughout the module students will critically evaluate a limited number of management plans for reserves that they visit and create a management plan for a fictional conservation scenario in the context of climate change. There will be a temporal delay to the release of different information in the fictional scenario to replicate a real world situation. This management plan will employ QGIS or similar GIS. This is worth 60% of the overall module mark. There is a reassessment opportunity in the normal reassessment period capped at 40%

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency and critical thinking, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessment are evidence based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

Reassessment strategy

Students will complete the same tasks but based on different scenarios and species. The mark will be capped at 40% and the reassessment will take place in the normal reassessment period. There is a resit opportunity.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Health and Safety
The MO is a qualified 1st aider. No lone fieldwork will be allowed.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Construct justified arguments for the value of conserving biodiversity.
 LO2 Critically evaluate the human activities that affect biodiversity and describe how they act individually and in combination to affect individuals, populations and ecosystems.
 LO3 Make linkages between theory and practice, particularly with regard to how ecological understanding is applied in conservation schemes that students visit.
 LO4 Critically evaluate, using case studies, and site visits, the pros and cons of a wide range of conservation interventions, from international legal instruments to local habitat management.
 LO5 Critically analyse where conservation questions can be answered with scientific evidence, and where socio-economic and other types of information are more important.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Problem solving skills
 S2 Communication skills
 S3 Ethical awareness
 S4 GIS
 S5 awareness of relevant UN sustainability goals

Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1. Invasive Species Action Plan (ISAP)
Professional ecologists and conservations are sometimes required to write Invasive Species Action Plans. Students will use GB Non-native Species Secretariat templates in order to complete this work and follow guidance set by the GB Invasive Non-native Species Strategy. As this is a novel assessment students will be provided with published ISAPs. They will also be given prescriptive guidance on how to complete the task which consist of six elements:
• Task 1. Rapid Risk Assessment – used to assess the likelihood and severity of the threat - completed form submitted in appendix with ISAP
• Task 2. Risk Management – used to evaluate management options - completed form submitted in appendix with ISAP
• Task 3. ISAP – produce an ISAP
• Task 4. NNSS ID sheet– produce an ID sheet
• Task 5. NNSS Species Fact Sheet (Alert Species)
• Task 6. Risk Communications Plan – the means by which the results of risk analysis are summarised and accurately communicated. You are not going to generate one of these but you simply need to say how you would communicate your findings

This is worth 40% of the overall module mark. There is a reassessment opportunity in the normal reassessment period capped at 40%

Assessment 2. Site management plan
Nature reserves often require both a short and long term site management plan that is written by the site manager and is a legally binding document. Throughout the module students will critically evaluate a limited number of management plans for reserves that they visit and create a management plan for a fictional conservation scenario in the context of climate change. There will be a temporal delay to the release of different information in the fictional scenario to replicate a real world situation. This management plan will employ QGIS or similar GIS. This is worth 60% of the overall module mark. There is a reassessment opportunity in the normal reassessment period capped at 40%

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency and critical thinking, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessment are evidence based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

Reassessment strategy

Students will complete the same tasks but based on different scenarios and species. The mark will be capped at 40% and the reassessment will take place in the normal reassessment period. There is a resit opportunity.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Construct justified arguments for the value of conserving biodiversity.
 LO2 Critically evaluate the human activities that affect biodiversity and describe how they act individually and in combination to affect individuals, populations and ecosystems.
 LO3 Make linkages between theory and practice, particularly with regard to how ecological understanding is applied in conservation schemes that students visit.
 LO4 Critically evaluate, using case studies, and site visits, the pros and cons of a wide range of conservation interventions, from international legal instruments to local habitat management.
 LO5 Critically analyse where conservation questions can be answered with scientific evidence, and where socio-economic and other types of information are more important.

Applied Conservation Biology 2026-27

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 6
Credits:15
Module Code:BIOS318
Delivery:Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 
In Programme:Zoology BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Details
Module Title
Applied Conservation Biology
Short Title
Applied Conservation Biology
Module Code
BIOS318
Academic Year
2026-27
Org Unit
Life Sciences NEW
Delivery Locations
Liverpool campus
Delivery Periods
Semester 2
Credits
15
Level
Level 6
Module Coordinator
Carl Larsen
Other Staff
Jenny Hodgson
Carl Larsen
Assigned To
Carl Larsen
Life and Human Sciences Admin
Marketing
Quality Team
Status
 
Approved
Date of Approval
9 Jan 2024, 16:06
Continuing Professional Development
No
Maximum Places
40
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This applied module uses research-connected teaching and field biology to explore contemporary thinking and practice in conservation biology in a practical setting. Students are encouraged to explore patterns of biodiversity and to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or decline of many animal and plant species. This equips students with the knowledge and skills to critically evaluate different approaches to conserving biodiversity at a range of locations including local nature reserves, agri-environment schemes and other non-designated areas.

The module is taught via lectures, tutorials and a series of non-residential field trips, where students will be tutored by, and work with site managers and practitioners to apply their understanding of biodiversity conservation. To support independent learning, students will also be guided to references, primary and secondary sources, listed by staff.

The module is assessed by an Invasive Species Action Plan and a site management plan.
Educational Aims
• develop in students knowledge and understanding about patterns of biodiversity and to enable them to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or decline of some animal and plant species.

• develop in students knowledge and deep understanding in conservation biology, and ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve complex problems in a real world setting.

• develop in students an awareness of the employment opportunities in conservation biology and what it takes to be career ready.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This applied module uses research-connected teaching, Geographical Information System (GIS) workshops, and field biology to explore contemporary thinking and practice in conservation biology in a practical setting. Students are encouraged to explore patterns of biodiversity and to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or decline of many animal and plant species. This equips students with the knowledge and skills to critically evaluate different approaches to conserving biodiversity at a range of local nature reserves and also in a global setting. Throughout the module, emphasis is placed on evidence-based approaches to conservation and how data gained are used to achieve maximally effective conservation and management.

The module is taught via lectures, tutorials and a series of non-residential field trips, where students will be tutored by, and work with site managers and conservation practitioners to apply their understanding of biodiversity conservation.

Students will gain practical experience of working on nature reserves that will prepare them for employment. They will develop their planning, management and leadership skills in conservation as well as an in-depth knowledge of applying QGIS to conservation questions. To support independent learning, students will also be guided to references, primary and secondary sources, listed by staff.

The module is assessed by an Invasive Species Action Plan and a Reserve Management Plan.

The module is aimed at students studying Biological Science, Bioveterinary Science and Zoology. The module will be of interest to students wishing to learn more about conservation biology, including those who wish to pursue a career in conservation or applied ecology.
Outline Syllabus
Theme: The bigger picture in Conservation Biology

This theme focuses on the scale and rate of species loss and fundamental causes of biodiversity erosion. Aspects of conservation biology that will be considered include, overexploitation of wildlife populations, the effects of climate change, and causes of habitat loss and disturbance. This will be taught through lectures and field visits.

Theme: Metapopulations and Conservation Genetics/Genomics

In this theme students will explore the importance of habitat area, fragmentation and connectivity and apply this to their understanding of species viability and to prioritise conservation efforts. They will study conservation genetics and use their understanding of species concepts, hybridization, genetic diversity, demographic history and effective population size to prioritise choices of species and protected areas. This will be taught through lectures and field visits.

Theme: Climate change and conservation

In this theme students will examine how climate change interferes with established conservation practices and necessitates different plans to achieve conservation goals

Theme: Decision making in conservation

In this theme students will explore how conservationists prioritise when making decisions about conservation practice and which areas and species to protect.

Theme: Economics of conservation

In this theme student will consider frameworks such as ‘land sparing-sharing’ which originated for quantifying and understanding the implications for wild species of using land in different ways to produce food. Students will also review ‘Eco-harvesting’. Students will also consider ‘Ecosystem services.’

Theme: Conservation practice

In this theme students will explore UK and Global conservation issues including invasive and alien species and hunting, lessons from past extinctions, captive breeding reintroductions, restoration, and designing nature reserves

Theme: Conservation careers

Students will work alongside conservationists and habitat managers and develop knowledge and skills in practical habitat management and species conservation, multiagency working, UK and global legislation and funding for conservation.
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week will involve watching pre-recorded material introducing the nature reserve, risk assessment etc, a 50 minute face to face lecture introducing key theory and a full day field visit. A tutorial will cover post-fieldwork discussions. There will be a block of workshops dedicated to teaching graphical information systems (GIS).

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled online lectures in which key concepts are explained and active learning tasks are set. There is one introductory lecture to each field trip. Each field trip will be preceded by a synchronous fieldwork preparation e-lecture.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 – Tutorials
Description: This refers to face-to-face tutorials to provide fieldwork follow-up
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 – workshops
Description: This refers to training students how to use QGIS
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 4 - Field trips
Description: This refers to site visits to various nature reserves, agri-schemes or other non-designated areas in the North West where students will be taught by, and work with conservation practitioners
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching method 5 – Self-directed learning
Description: This refers to independent study from online resources and texts, encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of virtual models, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, fieldwork, revision study and work towards assessment.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Due to the novel nature of the assessments students will receive formative feedback.

Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc and many hours of fieldwork. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Because the assessments are novel students are provided with formative feedback. The ISAP and the Reserve Management Plan are highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge and application in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning, using GIS, and real world case-based-learning etc. These foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures and field trips are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Both assessments require students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: Organisms and ecosystems are studied at a local and global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Lecture content, and discussion between students and staff will have a global perspective and give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1. Invasive Species Action Plan (ISAP)
Professional ecologists and conservations are sometimes required to write Invasive Species Action Plans. Students will use GB Non-native Species Secretariat templates in order to complete this work and follow guidance set by the GB Invasive Non-native Species Strategy. As this is a novel assessment students will be provided with published ISAPs. They will also be given prescriptive guidance on how to complete the task which consist of six elements:
• Task 1. Rapid Risk Assessment – used to assess the likelihood and severity of the threat - completed form submitted in appendix with ISAP
• Task 2. Risk Management – used to evaluate management options - completed form submitted in appendix with ISAP
• Task 3. ISAP – produce an ISAP
• Task 4. NNSS ID sheet– produce an ID sheet
• Task 5. NNSS Species Fact Sheet (Alert Species)
• Task 6. Risk Communications Plan – the means by which the results of risk analysis are summarised and accurately communicated. You are not going to generate one of these but you simply need to say how you would communicate your findings

This is worth 40% of the overall module mark. There is a reassessment opportunity in the normal reassessment period capped at 40%

Assessment 2. Site management plan
Nature reserves often require both a short and long term site management plan that is written by the site manager and is a legally binding document. Throughout the module students will critically evaluate a limited number of management plans for reserves that they visit and create a management plan for a fictional conservation scenario in the context of climate change. There will be a temporal delay to the release of different information in the fictional scenario to replicate a real world situation. This management plan will employ QGIS or similar GIS. This is worth 60% of the overall module mark. There is a reassessment opportunity in the normal reassessment period capped at 40%

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency and critical thinking, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessment are evidence based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

Reassessment strategy

Students will complete the same tasks but based on different scenarios and species. The mark will be capped at 40% and the reassessment will take place in the normal reassessment period. There is a resit opportunity.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Health and Safety
The MO is a qualified 1st aider. No lone fieldwork will be allowed.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Notes
This is a new module designed for the 2024 revalidation of zoology. It is due to start in 2026.

In this theme students will explore how conservationists prioritise when making decisions about conservation practice and which areas and species to protect.

Theme: Economics of conservation

In this theme student will consider frameworks such as ‘land sparing-sharing’ which originated for quantifying and understanding the implications for wild species of using land in different ways to produce food. Students will also review ‘Eco-harvesting’. Students will also consider ‘Ecosystem services.’

Theme: Conservation practice

In this theme students will explore UK and Global conservation issues including invasive and alien species and hunting, lessons from past extinctions, captive breeding reintroductions, restoration, and designing nature reserves

Theme: Conservation careers

Students will work alongside conservationists and habitat managers and develop knowledge and skills in practical habitat management and species conservation, multiagency working, UK and global legislation and funding for conservation.
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week will involve watching pre-recorded material introducing the nature reserve, risk assessment etc, a 50 minute face to face lecture introducing key theory and a full day field visit. A tutorial will cover post-fieldwork discussions. There will be a block of workshops dedicated to teaching graphical information systems (GIS).

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled online lectures in which key concepts are explained and active learning tasks are set. There is one introductory lecture to each field trip. Each field trip will be preceded by a synchronous fieldwork preparation e-lecture.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 – Tutorials
Description: This refers to face-to-face tutorials to provide fieldwork follow-up
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 – workshops
Description: This refers to training students how to use QGIS
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 4 - Field trips
Description: This refers to site visits to various nature reserves, agri-schemes or other non-designated areas in the North West where students will be taught by, and work with conservation practitioners
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching method 5 – Self-directed learning
Description: This refers to independent study from online resources and texts, encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of virtual models, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, fieldwork, revision study and work towards assessment.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Due to the novel nature of the assessments students will receive formative feedback.

Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc and many hours of fieldwork. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Because the assessments are novel students are provided with formative feedback. The ISAP and the Reserve Management Plan are highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge and application in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning, using GIS, and real world case-based-learning etc. These foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures and field trips are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Both assessments require students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: Organisms and ecosystems are studied at a local and global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Lecture content, and discussion between students and staff will have a global perspective and give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1. Invasive Species Action Plan (ISAP)
Professional ecologists and conservations are sometimes required to write Invasive Species Action Plans. Students will use GB Non-native Species Secretariat templates in order to complete this work and follow guidance set by the GB Invasive Non-native Species Strategy. As this is a novel assessment students will be provided with published ISAPs. They will also be given prescriptive guidance on how to complete the task which consist of six elements:
• Task 1. Rapid Risk Assessment – used to assess the likelihood and severity of the threat - completed form submitted in appendix with ISAP
• Task 2. Risk Management – used to evaluate management options - completed form submitted in appendix with ISAP
• Task 3. ISAP – produce an ISAP
• Task 4. NNSS ID sheet– produce an ID sheet
• Task 5. NNSS Species Fact Sheet (Alert Species)
• Task 6. Risk Communications Plan – the means by which the results of risk analysis are summarised and accurately communicated. You are not going to generate one of these but you simply need to say how you would communicate your findings

This is worth 40% of the overall module mark. There is a reassessment opportunity in the normal reassessment period capped at 40%

Assessment 2. Site management plan
Nature reserves often require both a short and long term site management plan that is written by the site manager and is a legally binding document. Throughout the module students will critically evaluate a limited number of management plans for reserves that they visit and create a management plan for a fictional conservation scenario in the context of climate change. There will be a temporal delay to the release of different information in the fictional scenario to replicate a real world situation. This management plan will employ QGIS or similar GIS. This is worth 60% of the overall module mark. There is a reassessment opportunity in the normal reassessment period capped at 40%

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency and critical thinking, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessment are evidence based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

Reassessment strategy

Students will complete the same tasks but based on different scenarios and species. The mark will be capped at 40% and the reassessment will take place in the normal reassessment period. There is a resit opportunity.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Health and Safety
The MO is a qualified 1st aider. No lone fieldwork will be allowed.

Blurb
Overview
This applied module uses research-connected teaching and field biology to explore contemporary thinking and practice in conservation biology in a practical setting. Students are encouraged to explore patterns of biodiversity and to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or decline of many animal and plant species. This equips students with the knowledge and skills to critically evaluate different approaches to conserving biodiversity at a range of locations including local nature reserves, agri-environment schemes and other non-designated areas.

The module is taught via lectures, tutorials and a series of non-residential field trips, where students will be tutored by, and work with site managers and practitioners to apply their understanding of biodiversity conservation. To support independent learning, students will also be guided to references, primary and secondary sources, listed by staff.

The module is assessed by an Invasive Species Action Plan and a site management plan.
Educational Aims
• develop in students knowledge and understanding about patterns of biodiversity and to enable them to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or decline of some animal and plant species.

• develop in students knowledge and deep understanding in conservation biology, and ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve complex problems in a real world setting.

• develop in students an awareness of the employment opportunities in conservation biology and what it takes to be career ready.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This applied module uses research-connected teaching, Geographical Information System (GIS) workshops, and field biology to explore contemporary thinking and practice in conservation biology in a practical setting. Students are encouraged to explore patterns of biodiversity and to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or decline of many animal and plant species. This equips students with the knowledge and skills to critically evaluate different approaches to conserving biodiversity at a range of local nature reserves and also in a global setting. Throughout the module, emphasis is placed on evidence-based approaches to conservation and how data gained are used to achieve maximally effective conservation and management.

The module is taught via lectures, tutorials and a series of non-residential field trips, where students will be tutored by, and work with site managers and conservation practitioners to apply their understanding of biodiversity conservation.

Students will gain practical experience of working on nature reserves that will prepare them for employment. They will develop their planning, management and leadership skills in conservation as well as an in-depth knowledge of applying QGIS to conservation questions. To support independent learning, students will also be guided to references, primary and secondary sources, listed by staff.

The module is assessed by an Invasive Species Action Plan and a Reserve Management Plan.

The module is aimed at students studying Biological Science, Bioveterinary Science and Zoology. The module will be of interest to students wishing to learn more about conservation biology, including those who wish to pursue a career in conservation or applied ecology.
Outline Syllabus
Theme: The bigger picture in Conservation Biology

This theme focuses on the scale and rate of species loss and fundamental causes of biodiversity erosion. Aspects of conservation biology that will be considered include, overexploitation of wildlife populations, the effects of climate change, and causes of habitat loss and disturbance. This will be taught through lectures and field visits.

Theme: Metapopulations and Conservation Genetics/Genomics

In this theme students will explore the importance of habitat area, fragmentation and connectivity and apply this to their understanding of species viability and to prioritise conservation efforts. They will study conservation genetics and use their understanding of species concepts, hybridization, genetic diversity, demographic history and effective population size to prioritise choices of species and protected areas. This will be taught through lectures and field visits.

Theme: Climate change and conservation

In this theme students will examine how climate change interferes with established conservation practices and necessitates different plans to achieve conservation goals

Theme: Decision making in conservation

In this theme students will explore how conservationists prioritise when making decisions about conservation practice and which areas and species to protect.

Theme: Economics of conservation

In this theme student will consider frameworks such as ‘land sparing-sharing’ which originated for quantifying and understanding the implications for wild species of using land in different ways to produce food. Students will also review ‘Eco-harvesting’. Students will also consider ‘Ecosystem services.’

Theme: Conservation practice

In this theme students will explore UK and Global conservation issues including invasive and alien species and hunting, lessons from past extinctions, captive breeding reintroductions, restoration, and designing nature reserves

Theme: Conservation careers

Students will work alongside conservationists and habitat managers and develop knowledge and skills in practical habitat management and species conservation, multiagency working, UK and global legislation and funding for conservation.

Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1. Invasive Species Action Plan (ISAP)
Professional ecologists and conservations are sometimes required to write Invasive Species Action Plans. Students will use GB Non-native Species Secretariat templates in order to complete this work and follow guidance set by the GB Invasive Non-native Species Strategy. As this is a novel assessment students will be provided with published ISAPs. They will also be given prescriptive guidance on how to complete the task which consist of six elements:
• Task 1. Rapid Risk Assessment – used to assess the likelihood and severity of the threat - completed form submitted in appendix with ISAP
• Task 2. Risk Management – used to evaluate management options - completed form submitted in appendix with ISAP
• Task 3. ISAP – produce an ISAP
• Task 4. NNSS ID sheet– produce an ID sheet
• Task 5. NNSS Species Fact Sheet (Alert Species)
• Task 6. Risk Communications Plan – the means by which the results of risk analysis are summarised and accurately communicated. You are not going to generate one of these but you simply need to say how you would communicate your findings

This is worth 40% of the overall module mark. There is a reassessment opportunity in the normal reassessment period capped at 40%

Assessment 2. Site management plan
Nature reserves often require both a short and long term site management plan that is written by the site manager and is a legally binding document. Throughout the module students will critically evaluate a limited number of management plans for reserves that they visit and create a management plan for a fictional conservation scenario in the context of climate change. There will be a temporal delay to the release of different information in the fictional scenario to replicate a real world situation. This management plan will employ QGIS or similar GIS. This is worth 60% of the overall module mark. There is a reassessment opportunity in the normal reassessment period capped at 40%

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency and critical thinking, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessment are evidence based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

Reassessment strategy

Students will complete the same tasks but based on different scenarios and species. The mark will be capped at 40% and the reassessment will take place in the normal reassessment period. There is a resit opportunity.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
